creator: schraubenonkel
title: Ultra Fast and Simple Colour Sensor
materials_required: RGB LED (ideally from a 12V RGB strip)
description: This project details the creation of a fast and low-cost color sensor using an RGB LED and a phototransistor. The sensor measures the reflection intensity of red, green, and blue light emitted by the LED to determine the RGB values of an object.
steps: Build the circuit on a breadboard or a milled board. Connect the green and blue LEDs with 470 Ohm resistors and the red LED with a 240 Ohm resistor. Connect the phototransistor with a 10k Ohm pull-down resistor. Ensure the transistor is placed directly next to the LED.

Understand the sensor's working principle: The RGB LED alternates between red, green, and blue light. For each color, the reflection intensity is measured. The analog value is read via the Arduino's ADC to obtain the RGB values of the object.
Connect the sensor to the Arduino using four free pins: gnd to gnd, 5V to 5V, out to A0, red to 2, blue to 3, and green to 4.
Copy the provided Arduino code into the Arduino IDE and compile it. Upload the code to your Arduino.
Open the serial monitor to view the RGB values. Ensure the sensor is positioned 0.5-1 cm away from the object for optimal performance.
